org_name: Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania
parent_system: Penn Medicine (University of Pennsylvania Health System)

request_pathways.name: Authorization for Disclosure of Health Information
Mail submission to Medical Records Department

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Penn Medicine directs patients wanting their own records to the myPennMedicine patient portal; a generic authorization PDF is available as a secondary pathway for all disclosure requests.

barriers.response_time_value: 30 days on-site, 60 days off-site, with possible 30-day extension
red_flags: Fee structure references state law rather than HIPAA cost-based limits for patient access, risking overcharging
Fax delivery explicitly restricted to urgent patient care situations only
PDF form submission requires physical mail — no fax or electronic submission of the form itself
bright_spots: 70 fillable interactive PDF fields — comprehensive digital completion capability
ADA-accessible PDF design with proper text encoding
Explicit patient self-access rights language within the authorization form
Granular record-type selection with 14 categories plus behavioral health/SUD opt-in
Radiology images explicitly free of charge
Denial/appeal rights clearly stated with Chief Privacy Officer contact

findability.rationale: Level 3: requires moderate effort — the form is not immediately discoverable from the homepage; patients must navigate to Patient Resources → Patient Access, and the official page was blocked by Incapsula bot protection requiring browser fallback.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 3: the PDF form has excellent fillable fields (70) but the form must be submitted via physical mail — fax is restricted, no electronic submission of the authorization form is available; the patient portal provides digital access but the PDF pathway itself requires paper mailing.

content_design.rationale: Level 4: well-organized two-page form with clear section structure, 14 granular record-type checkboxes, separate behavioral health/SUD consent sections, and thorough page-2 instructions; minor issues include unexplained 'Label Area' placeholder and ambulatory carve-out buried in instructions.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 3: the authorization form is a generic HIPAA disclosure form not designed for patient self-access — patients must fill in their own name as recipient; however, the org does direct patients to the portal for self-access and the form includes an explicit patient rights acknowledgment.

compliance.rationale: Level 4: no notarization required, treatment explicitly not conditioned on signing, HIPAA-aligned response timelines (30/60 days), denial/appeal rights stated; minor ambiguity in fee disclosure referencing state law rather than HIPAA patient access fee limits.

overall.summary: Penn Medicine offers a technically well-crafted fillable PDF and directs patients to a portal for self-access, but the paper authorization form is a generic HIPAA disclosure that requires mail submission and does not distinguish patient access from third-party release.
